Datalight Common Libraries Overview

Send comments on this topic.
Welcome to the Datalight Common Libraries (DCL). This product is included as a component in other Datalight products, and this documentation is intended to be both operating system and product independent.

Overview

DCL is a shared component that is used for multiple Datalight products. This component includes a wide variety of functionality that addresses common needs. DCL is typically installed in the \ProductRoot\dcl directory, one level below wherever the master Datalight product is installed.

DCL is designed to be seamlessly included by other Datalight products. In many cases the master Datalight product will encapsulate the DCL functionality in a way that hides it from the general developer. Using DCL functionality is done by including dcl.h in a source module, however this is typically done automatically by the master product's main header file.

DCL "knows" that it is being included by another product, however it does know specific details about that product.

DCL Components

DCL consists of the following primary components, listed below.

Build Process Abstraction

Datalight products use a standard build process when running on a Windows hosted development system. The product independent portions of this build process are implemented in DCL, in the \dcl\host\win32 directory tree, with some supporting headers located in \dcl\include\toolset.

C Library Abstraction

A pseudo standard C library set of functionality is included. This functionality is specifically designed to support the needs of Datalight products and is not intended to be a general C library replacement. This functionality is implemented in the \dcl\common\clib directory. See the specific function documentation for information regarding API compatibility with the C standard.

Utility Functions

A set of generalized utility functions are implemented in the \dcl\common\util directory. These functions include such things as memory management, semaphore and mutex management, and timer facilities. The DCL API Reference provides documentation for these functions.

OS Services Abstraction

Operating system specific services are abstracted in the \dcl\os\wince\services directory. These functions are documented in the DCL API Reference.

Macros

DCL includes a number of helper macros, most of which are implemented in dlmacros.h.

Tests

DCL includes a number of tests which exercise the various DCL components:

DCLTEST - A general unit test of DCL functionality.
DEVIOTEST - A block device I/O test, which tests functionality and performance.
FSIOTEST - A file system I/O test, which tests functionality and performance.

These tests are implemented in the \dcl\common\tests directory.

Standard Data Types

DCL implements a standard set of fixed width data types, upon which most other data types are built. These data types are implemented in the ToolSet specific header file.

DCL Project Settings

Each project has a dclconf.h file, which is placed in the Project Directory whenever a new project is created. This header file is used to configure DCL. For most operating systems, this header file rarely needs to be changed for general product use. See the product specific documentation for more details on configuring DCL for product related needs.

Using Multiple Products with DCL

If you are using multiple Datalight products, each may come with its own copy of DCL, and the DCL versions may not match. If the two Datalight products are independently built (compiled), and then linked together, two separate copies of DCL will be included. This eliminates problems due to version dependencies.

If the two products are using the exact same version of DCL (same build number), then it is possible to have the two products share the same DCL libraries. Please contact Datalight for more information on how to configure this option.

API Mapping

All public DCL functions are declared using the DCLFUNC macro. This macro resolves differently depending on the master Datalight product being used. This allows two different Datalight products to include two different versions of DCL, without namespace conflicts (as described earlier).

In addition to this API mapping, DCL allows some of its API functions to be overridden, either at the operating system level, or at the project level. In particular, this functionality is enabled for the "C-Library" DCL API, in the header file dlapimap.h.

This allows each given OS port for DCL to map the C-Library APIs as appropriate for the system, and allows them to be overridden at the project level if necessary.

For example, it is not uncommon to find broken C-Library memset implementations, either in the OS or in the tool chain. The DclMemSet() macro, implemented in dlapimap.h can be overridden, either in the OS-specific dlosconf.h, or in the project's dclconf.h to use the DCL internal implementation of memset.
